#Text=CHAPTER XIII -- OOLANGA'S HALLUCINATIONS
#Text=During the last few days Lady
#Text=Arabella had been getting exceedingly impatient .
#Text=Her debts , always pressing , were growing to an embarrassing amount .

#Text=The only hope she had of comfort in life was a good marriage ; but the good marriage on which she had fixed her eye did not seem to move quickly enough -- indeed , it did not seem to move at all -- in the right direction .
#Text=Edgar Caswall was not an ardent wooer .
#Text=From the very first he seemed difficile , but he had been keeping to his own room ever since his struggle with Mimi Watford .

#Text=On that occasion Lady Arabella had shown him in an unmistakable way what her feelings were ; indeed , she had made it known to him , in a more overt way than pride should allow , that she wished to help and support him .
#Text=The moment when she had gone across the room to stand beside him in his mesmeric struggle , had been the very limit of her voluntary action .

#Text=It was quite bitter enough , she felt , that he did not come to her , but now that she had made that advance , she felt that any withdrawal on his part would , to a woman of her class , be nothing less than a flaming insult .
#Text=Had she not classed herself with his nigger servant , an unreformed savage ?
#Text=Had she not shown her preference for him at the festival of his home-coming ?
#Text=Had she not . . .
#Text=Lady Arabella was cold-blooded , and she was prepared to go through all that might be necessary of indifference , and even insult , to become chatelaine of Castra Regis .
#Text=In the meantime , she would show no hurry -- she must wait .
#Text=She might , in an unostentatious way , come to him again .
#Text=She knew him now , and could make a keen guess at his desires with regard to Lilla Watford .
#Text=With that secret in her possession , she could bring pressure to bear on Caswall which would make it no easy matter for him to evade her .
#Text=The great difficulty was how to get near him .
#Text=He was shut up within his Castle , and guarded by a defence of convention which she could not pass without danger of ill repute to herself .
#Text=Over this question she thought and thought for days and nights .
#Text=At last she decided that the only way would be to go to him openly at Castra Regis .
#Text=Her rank and position would make such a thing possible , if carefully done .
#Text=She could explain matters afterwards if necessary .
#Text=Then when they were alone , she would use her arts and her experience to make him commit himself .
#Text=After all , he was only a man , with a man 's dislike of difficult or awkward situations .
#Text=She felt quite sufficient confidence in her own womanhood to carry her through any difficulty which might arise .
#Text=From Diana 's Grove she heard each day the luncheon-gong from Castra Regis sound , and knew the hour when the servants would be in the back of the house .
#Text=She would enter the house at that hour , and , pretending that she could not make anyone hear her , would seek him in his own rooms .
#Text=The tower was , she knew , away from all the usual sounds of the house , and moreover she knew that the servants had strict orders not to interrupt him when he was in the turret chamber .

#Text=She had found out , partly by the aid of an opera-glass and partly by judicious questioning , that several times lately a heavy chest had been carried to and from his room , and that it rested in the room each night .
#Text=She was , therefore , confident that he had some important work on hand which would keep him busy for long spells .
#Text=Meanwhile , another member of the household at Castra Regis had schemes which he thought were working to fruition .
#Text=A man in the position of a servant has plenty of opportunity of watching his betters and forming opinions regarding them .
#Text=Oolanga was in his way a clever , unscrupulous rogue , and he felt that with things moving round him in this great household there should be opportunities of self-advancement .
#Text=Being unscrupulous and stealthy -- and a savage -- he looked to dishonest means .
#Text=He saw plainly enough that Lady Arabella was making a dead set at his master , and he was watchful of the slightest sign of anything which might enhance this knowledge .

#Text=Like the other men in the house , he knew of the carrying to and fro of the great chest , and had got it into his head that the care exercised in its porterage indicated that it was full of treasure .
#Text=He was for ever lurking around the turret-rooms on the chance of making some useful discovery .
#Text=But he was as cautious as he was stealthy , and took care that no one else watched him .
#Text=It was thus that the negro became aware of Lady Arabella 's venture into the house , as she thought , unseen .
#Text=He took more care than ever , since he was watching another , that the positions were not reversed .
#Text=More than ever he kept his eyes and ears open and his mouth shut .
#Text=Seeing Lady Arabella gliding up the stairs towards his master 's room , he took it for granted that she was there for no good , and doubled his watching intentness and caution .
